description.value: The lowest possible reference level for hunting the weakest signals imaginable.
Deep noise floor — ideal for weak signal hunting.
Deep noise floor — ideal for weak signal hunting.
Below typical ambient RF noise — for sensitive receivers.
Below typical ambient RF noise — for sensitive receivers.
Below typical ambient RF noise — for sensitive receivers.
Below typical ambient RF noise — for sensitive receivers.
Quiet environment, low-level signals clearly visible.
Quiet environment, low-level signals clearly visible.
Quiet environment, low-level signals clearly visible.
Quiet environment, low-level signals clearly visible.
Good general-purpose reference level.
Good general-purpose reference level.
Good general-purpose reference level.
Good general-purpose reference level.
Stronger signals, moderate local RF traffic.
Stronger signals, moderate local RF traffic.
Stronger signals, moderate local RF traffic.
Stronger signals, moderate local RF traffic.
For strong broadcast transmitters or test signals.
For strong broadcast transmitters or test signals.
For strong broadcast transmitters or test signals.
For strong broadcast transmitters or test signals.
Max headroom — use with caution to avoid clipping.
Max headroom — use with caution to avoid clipping.
Turns on the pre-amplifier. A monstrous gain for weak signals.
Turns off the pre-amplifier. The scanner returns to its natural, less monstrous state.
Activates high-sensitivity mode. The scanner now listens for the whispers of the universe.
Deactivates high-sensitivity mode. The scanner's ears are no longer superhuman.
No attenuation. Full power! Use with caution.
A light filter, for when the signal is just a bit too spicy.
A good, solid filter for moderate signals.
A strong filter for powerful signals. Like wearing sunglasses to the beach.
A heavy filter for blaringly strong signals. It's like wearing a blindfold on a sunny day.
Extreme attenuation for signals that could damage the instrument.
Like a race car: fast sweep, low detail. Best for catching fleeting signals.
A jog through the spectrum; quick enough to see the sights without missing much.
The perfect balance of speed and fidelity. Not too fast, not too slow.
A calm stroll, giving you time to appreciate the finer signal details.
A slow saunter through the noise floor, where every waveform is a work of art.
For the patient scientist. You'll see things nobody else can, but it'll take a while.
So slow you can practically see the electrons move. The highest fidelity, but you'll miss any quick events.
So slow you can practically see the electrons move. The highest fidelity, but you'll miss any quick events.
A lightning-fast sweep. Filters are wide open, letting everything through.
A quick pass through the spectrum, ideal for fast-changing signals.
A balanced speed for general purpose monitoring and signal capture.
The standard filter setting for most common analysis tasks. Not too much, not too little.
A gentle filter, giving you more time to appreciate the finer details of a waveform.
For the meticulous scientist. You'll filter out fast noise and jitter, but at the cost of speed.
A meditative pace. So slow you can practically see the electrons move, offering maximum stability and noise reduction.
A slow crawl. Good for very detailed analysis of continuous signals and filtering out transient noise.
A slow crawl. Good for very detailed analysis of continuous signals and filtering out transient noise.
The scanner cries, but it's worth it. Filters out almost all random noise, giving you a crystal-clear, steady line.
The scanner cries, but it's worth it. Filters out almost all random noise, giving you a crystal-clear, steady line.
Time seems to stop. For the most patient scientists and signals with incredible stability. The ultimate low-pass filter.
Time seems to stop. For the most patient scientists and signals with incredible stability. The ultimate low-pass filter.
So tight you'll feel like a cellular biologist examining a single-cell waveform.
A narrow, focused view for getting up close and personal with signals.
The standard span, a balanced diet for most common analysis.
A broad, digestible view of the spectrum, great for general reconnaissance.
A very broad span for finding signals over a large frequency range. It's like scanning with a wide-angle lens.
A very broad span for finding signals over a large frequency range. It's like scanning with a wide-angle lens.
A very broad span for finding signals over a large frequency range. It's like scanning with a wide-angle lens.
Captures and displays the trace in real time, like a hyperactive surveillance camera.
Keeps the highest-level peaks on display, like a digital trophy case for signals.
Holds onto the lowest points, great for detecting signals that vanish in the noise.
Clears the slate, preparing for a new scan. A zen state for the scanner.
The standard mode, simply viewing the current sweep data.
Captures and displays the trace in real time, like a hyperactive surveillance camera.
Keeps the highest-level peaks on display, like a digital trophy case for signals.
Holds onto the lowest points, great for detecting signals that vanish in the noise.
Clears the slate, preparing for a new scan. A zen state for the scanner.
The standard mode, simply viewing the current sweep data.
Captures and displays the trace in real time, like a hyperactive surveillance camera.
Keeps the highest-level peaks on display, like a digital trophy case for signals.
Holds onto the lowest points, great for detecting signals that vanish in the noise.
Clears the slate, preparing for a new scan. A zen state for the scanner.
The standard mode, simply viewing the current sweep data.
Captures and displays the trace in real time, like a hyperactive surveillance camera.
Keeps the highest-level peaks on display, like a digital trophy case for signals.
Holds onto the lowest points, great for detecting signals that vanish in the noise.
Clears the slate, preparing for a new scan. A zen state for the scanner.
The standard mode, simply viewing the current sweep data.
Turns on continuous sweep mode. The scanner never rests!
Turns off continuous sweep mode. The scanner will perform a single sweep and then rest.
Just a raw, single sweep. Great for seeing fast changes and fleeting events, but the noise floor is high and the trace is very jittery.
A very mild smoothing of the signal, removing some of the jitter. It's like putting a slight damper on the noise, making the trace a little easier to read.
The trace becomes noticeably less fuzzy. The random spikes of the noise floor start to settle down, revealing more consistent signals.
A good balance of noise reduction and display speed. The noise floor is clean, and low-level, stable signals are clearly visible.
The noise floor is now very stable and appears as a thin line. You're only seeing the most consistent signals and cutting out most of the random interference.
This setting is for serious analysis. It's a highly stable trace that filters out a large portion of the ambient RF noise, allowing for precise measurements of continuous signals.
For when only the cleanest signal will do. This high level of averaging provides a virtually noise-free display, perfect for scientific or very low-level signal detection.
A deep and thorough look at the spectrum. All but the most stable signals are averaged out, offering a truly pristine view of the fundamental RF environment.
An incredibly slow and deliberate pace. This is for long-term monitoring, allowing you to see the overall shape of the spectrum with almost all noise removed.
For the patient and the meticulous. This is the ultimate level of noise reduction, yielding an exceptionally smooth and stable trace for the most demanding analysis.
